text.title: Start a Primary School Media and School Newspaper Publishing Company
text.head: Start a Primary School Media and School Newspaper Publishing Company
text.p: Are you keen on running your own mini-media empire at an early age in school? This can be a fantastic grounding for a future career and gives you a very early opportunity to learn about managing people, deadlines, and expectations. This article provides a brief overview of the things to consider when developing your publishing company.
text.head: Steps

list.item:
Build your team of at least 4 "staff". You will likely have to double up on a number of the tasks and have each person responsible for several jobs. Jobs could be:
reporter
photographer
editor
sub-editor
picture-editor
columnists
researchers

You will also need to consider the need for a:
complaints officer; and/or a PR Manager

In addition to your staff you may need a board of directors, consisting of:
A President, Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary, and representatives from all 4 classes, the board of directors President, VP, Treasurer and Secretary should be appointed by the representatives, and the representatives should be appointed be the class officers.
Give your newspapers(s) a cutting edge name. Brainstorm with your team for a suitable name.
Decide how many pages you will have and what will be the contents.
Use a page layout and word processing program to build your paper. Suggestions are in tips.
Cut down on ink and paper; try to get your school to print it.

Decide a price, it can be free if you have ads in it or sponsors. Your team will need to go around and rally sponsors and funds for it if you do not sell it. Even if you have sponsorship, you might need to sell it to cover overheads and to give the paper value in people's minds. People often dismiss that which is freely given.

Try to get people into it. Be a motivator and sell the virtues of being a part of the newspaper team for their future careers, their sense of community involvement and their love of helping others and writing. Be careful not to overdo it though and use people up. Everyone deserves a fair go and nobody should be left feeling that they have been used up when they are volunteering their time, efforts, and ideas. Recognize their efforts and reward them in appropriate ways as possible.

text.head: Tips

list.item: Write your articles in a word-processor first. Suggestions include OpenOffice.org Writer, Corel WordPerfect, AbiWord, Apple Pages and Microsoft Word.

Use desktop publishing (DTP) software. The industry standard is QuarkXPress and Adobe InDesign, but for a free alternative, try Scribus. A cheap alternative is Serif PagePlus. If you already paid for Microsoft Office, there is Publisher in some (but not all) editions.
